I am not quite sure how you developed the idea that I was supporting the 
confederates. I hate the bastards; as a libertarian, I cannot stand a 
society that allows enslavement of anyone. 

I was just informing you how the person who criticized was right, and how 
you were wrong. People do not enslave others just for sake of enslaving 
them. They do not take the time to enslave people merely because they think 
the people are lesser than them. They enslave because they need cheap labor 
to work their massive farms. And as I said, at the beginning of the civil 
war, in 1861, the Southern United States, the states that would succeed and 
join the CSA, were the fifth largest economy in the World, because they 
produced an insane amount of agricultural products. Their motivator to 
succeed was the threat against slavery, which would decimate their economy 
(and it did afterwards). The motive was economic, not racial. They did not 
fight just so they could keep the blacks down, they fought so they could 
keep themselves up.

I am not an apologist, I am not historically ignorant. Arguably, I know 
much more about this issue than you do. Lincoln was not in favor of or 
supportive of blacks. He was an abolitionist, yes, but he wanted them freed 
just so he could send them back to Africa, where he thought they belonged. 
Lincoln was racist, his policies were purely tactical and economic. If he 
cared about blacks, he would have freed every person held as a slave in the 
North. It was not until his vice president, Johnson, took office that 
slavery was outlawed in the United States.

I never discussed states rights, because I am not arguing in favor of the 
confederates. The CSA was terrible, their existence and their policies were 
atrocious. I have never tried to argue in their favor. I was just 
correcting you, when you said that the war was not economic. It was, and 
Lincoln was no hero.

+Braden Gilleland I didn't state a cause, but of course you would assume I 
meant slavery. Sensitive?

But regardless, slavery was the primary cause of the war, Lincoln was an 
abolitionist because they tried co-existence, but the south kept pushing 
retarded laws into the rest of the country.

For example, a slave owner could take his slaves into a so called free 
state, and still keep them as slaves, despite the fact that slavery was 
 illegal. It went so far as to extend to buying out of state slaves and 
importing them in to keep as slaves was allowed, and slave hunters could 
cross state lines to nab former slaves and return them to slavery.

You want to talk about states rights being violated? How about the right to 
not have slaves in your fucking state. Slave owners weren't all "states 
rights" when they were on the violating end, I see no reason why I should 
sympathize with them when they got their shit violated right back.

And on to the main economy point, that's a side issue. The problem wasn't 
the robustness of their economy, but the fact that they used slaves to get 
it. If that economy had been built any other way, or transitioned out of 
slavery, the civil war would not have happened. Slavery is the linchpin, 
the main issue, that began the conflict, and the main sticking point 
throughout it.

I find extremely irritating how apologists like yourself try to paint the 
issue as everything but the south being filled with slaves. Is the truth 
too uncomfortable for you? Do you not want to admit that the confederates 
weren't heroes or patriots, but nothing more than dirty slaves trading 
sacks of shit? Does that hurt your feelings?

+darkmantlestudios Actually, no, that was an incredibly significant part of 
the Civil War. The south was so opposed to the new republican party, who 
favored abolitionism, that, when Lincoln was elected, they succeeded to 
ensure that slavery was not outlawed immediately, which would decimate the 
then fifth largest economy in the World. Now of course they were racist, 
and slavery was an undertone of the entire war, but at no point was it the 
most important thing. Lincoln was not a staunch abolitionist; he was not a 
fan of blacks. When he signed the Emancipation Proclamation, it only 
affected the slaves in the south, it did nothing to free slaves held in the 
North. Also, Lincoln at many points in his life favored shipping Blacks off 
to the American African nations, Liberia and Sierra Lione. 

The economy was central to the Civil War, Slavery just happened to be the 
backbone of the southern economy, and thus why they so opposed an 
"abolitionist" like Lincoln.

Anybody who embraces Darwinian ideologies of capitalism in general and 
especially in government administration is obviously going to have racist 
tendencies.  Former southern democrats and the current GOP have always 
pandered to this group of the electorate not because they're inherently 
racist but because those conservative values are generally espoused by 
people who do not seek or want government intervention in their personal 
failures. 

To them, having such a system also allows their competitors an equal 
footing at success whereas for them, there is already a privatized 
community of support (grandfather, rich uncle, a bank, inheritance) where 
they can reach out to if this occurs to them.  In their mind, if you get 
hungry and run out of money or lose your home, you should be allowed to 
fail and relinquish your chattel to someone who is more suitable to use it. 

Basically...f**k off and go die out somewhere.  This is one of the 
cornerstones of our American N.I.M.B.Y. mentality.  While this 
ideology does transcend race/ethnicity, it is one of the primary modalities 
for entrenched racism to fester.  So the parties who have had 
anti-egalitarian ideology have always found themselves inundated by 
racists, either closeted or exposed and rich and poor. 

What's ironic is that if you were to put these same people in situations 
where the tables were turned, either because of financial or environmental 
factors, their Darwinian thinking will fly right out of the window. 

For example, let's say a deeply conservative republican senator from 
Mississippi was touring an Australian safari and by some luck of nature got 
lost and stripped of his personal belongings, he'd gladly accept any aid 
he'd receive from anybody in order to survive (fend off wild creatures that 
live by this form of Darwinism), be it in the form of money, water, food, 
hospitalization or a sponsored flight back to the US. 

While this is an extreme example, it just highlights the reality that, to 
those individuals, that this ideology only applies to people other than 
themselves who might take the reigns of the economy and society as a 
whole, back from them.

What this all really boils down to is that over time, the haves become 
frustrated with the have-nots because as they gain a better edge from their 
already exuberant advantage, the have-nots continue to seek out ways to 
equalize the system built to keep them in or around the level they are on 
the pyramid. 

The have-nots embrace egalitarianism because they feel it will give them a 
fairer chance at success as it did for those who came before them who took 
advantage of such systems whereas the haves embrace 
"Laissez-faire" ideology which will permit them to maintain their advantage 
and manage their enclaves of success (CEO, Dr., Attorney, Judge, 
Billionaire) and remain the gatekeepers to the nation's upward mobility 
potentials.  This is not always the truth, but in their mind it is believed 
to be a facet of reality.﻿

Personally I think that studies like this are very important. It gives us 
an idea of what percentage of the population still has racist thoughts, and 
allows us to make educated strategies on where to target the problem.

If this study had a general geological location of these participants, it 
will allow us to see where the problem most resides, and kick start anti 
racism educational campaigns in those areas.

With all of that said, I am a strong believer in the idea that racism would 
go away if the issue was never brought up as a concern during early 
upbringing. For instance, if you never introduce children to the idea that 
you can separate people by race, and make stereotypical judgements based on 
those parameters, than the idea to separate people because of that criteria 
would never arise during their development.﻿

This study has imperfect questions created 40years ago, and carried forward 
for the sake of data continuity. 

In best-test construction, if we cared explicitly to get at the heart of 
racial bias, we would design multiple indirect questions, vetted against 
concurrent validity measures, to give us aggregate scoring that would 
statistically differentiate one group from another. 

I agree with John; this is an old, imperfect study, but there is some value 
in seeing trends with minimal adverse impacts. While UoV is a wonderful 
school, degrees from a top 10 are not tantamount to omnipotence in research 
utility. ﻿
